questions.question: The going concern assumption presumes that an entity will:

options.A: Grow by at least 5% annually
options.B: Continue in operation for the foreseeable future
options.C: Eventually be acquired by another company

questions.explanation: The going concern assumption presumes the entity will continue operations for a reasonable period without liquidation. Financial statements are prepared on this basis unless liquidation is imminent.
questions.tip: Going concern = will continue operating. Not about growth, just survival.

questions.question: Primary responsibility for evaluating the entity's ability to continue as a going concern rests with:

options.A: The external auditor
options.B: Management

questions.explanation: Management has primary responsibility for evaluating the entity's ability to continue as a going concern, including assessing conditions and developing plans to address any substantial doubt.
questions.tip: Management evaluates going concern. Auditor evaluates management's assessment.

questions.question: Under GAAP, management evaluates going concern for a period of:

options.A: Six months from the balance sheet date
options.B: One year from the date the financial statements are issued
options.C: Two years from the balance sheet date

questions.explanation: Under ASC 205-40, management evaluates whether there is substantial doubt about the entity's ability to continue as a going concern for one year from the date the financial statements are issued (or available to be issued).
questions.tip: GAAP = one year from issuance date. Not from balance sheet date.

questions.question: Substantial doubt about an entity's ability to continue as a going concern exists when:

options.A: Any uncertainty about the future exists
options.B: Conditions and events indicate it is probable the entity cannot meet obligations as they come due
options.C: The entity has reported a net loss

questions.explanation: Substantial doubt exists when conditions and events, considered in the aggregate, indicate it is probable that the entity will be unable to meet its obligations as they become due within the look-forward period.
questions.tip: Substantial doubt = probable inability to meet obligations. Not just any uncertainty.

questions.question: Which condition may raise substantial doubt about going concern?

options.A: Strong cash flows from operations
options.B: Negative trends such as recurring losses and working capital deficiencies

questions.explanation: Negative trends like recurring operating losses, negative cash flows, working capital deficiencies, and loan defaults are indicators that may raise substantial doubt about going concern.
questions.tip: Red flags: recurring losses, negative cash flow, working capital deficit, debt defaults.

questions.question: When evaluating going concern, the auditor should:

options.A: Only consider conditions at the balance sheet date
options.B: Evaluate conditions through the date of the auditor's report
options.D: Perform procedures only if management identifies concerns

questions.explanation: The auditor should evaluate conditions and events from the balance sheet date through the report date, considering all information obtained during the audit that may bear on the entity's ability to continue.
questions.tip: Auditor evaluates through report date. Consider all evidence obtained.

questions.question: When evaluating management's plans to mitigate going concern, the auditor should consider:

options.A: Only plans that have been fully implemented
options.B: The feasibility of plans and likelihood they will be effective within the time frame
options.C: All plans regardless of probability of success
options.D: Only plans approved by the audit committee

questions.explanation: The auditor evaluates whether management's plans are feasible, can be effectively implemented, and whether they will mitigate the conditions raising substantial doubt within the evaluation period.
questions.tip: Plans must be feasible + likely to be effective + timely. Not just good intentions.

questions.question: When substantial doubt exists but adequate disclosure is made, the auditor should:

options.A: Issue an adverse opinion
options.B: Issue an unmodified opinion with an emphasis-of-matter paragraph

questions.explanation: When substantial doubt exists and adequate disclosure is made, the auditor issues an unmodified opinion with an emphasis-of-matter paragraph referring to the going concern uncertainty.
questions.tip: Adequate disclosure + substantial doubt = unmodified opinion + emphasis paragraph.

questions.question: When substantial doubt exists, required disclosures include:

options.A: Only a statement that the company may not survive
options.B: Principal conditions raising doubt, management's evaluation and plans, and possible effects
options.C: Names of creditors who may not be paid
options.D: The exact date the company will cease operations

questions.explanation: Disclosures must include the principal conditions giving rise to substantial doubt, management's evaluation of those conditions and plans to address them, and the possible effects on the financial statements.
questions.tip: Disclose: conditions + management's evaluation + plans + possible effects.

questions.question: If substantial doubt exists but management does not provide adequate disclosure:

options.A: The auditor should only include an emphasis paragraph
options.B: The auditor should modify the opinion due to departure from GAAP
options.C: The auditor should issue an unmodified opinion

questions.explanation: Inadequate disclosure of going concern conditions represents a GAAP departure. The auditor should issue a qualified or adverse opinion, depending on materiality and pervasiveness.
questions.tip: Missing disclosure = GAAP departure = qualified or adverse opinion.

questions.question: Which financial indicator most directly suggests going concern problems?

options.A: Decreasing gross profit margin
options.B: Inability to pay debts as they come due

questions.explanation: The inability to pay debts as they become due is the most direct indicator of going concern problems, as it suggests the entity cannot meet its obligations, which is the core of the going concern evaluation.
questions.tip: Can't pay debts when due = fundamental going concern issue.

questions.question: Operating indicators of going concern problems include:

options.A: Introduction of new products
options.B: Loss of key management, customers, or suppliers

questions.explanation: Loss of key management, major customers, important suppliers, or key employees can threaten an entity's ability to continue operations, especially if replacements are not readily available.
questions.tip: Loss of key people/relationships = operating threat to going concern.

questions.question: External indicators of potential going concern issues include:

options.A: Favorable industry trends
options.B: Legal proceedings or new regulations that could jeopardize operations

questions.explanation: Legal proceedings that could result in claims the entity cannot satisfy, or new regulations that could force closure, are external factors that may raise substantial doubt about going concern.
questions.tip: External threats: legal actions, regulation changes, market collapse.

questions.question: Management's plans that may alleviate substantial doubt include:

options.A: Vague intentions to improve operations
options.B: Plans to dispose of assets, obtain financing, or reduce costs that are feasible and probable

questions.explanation: Plans that can alleviate substantial doubt include disposing of assets, borrowing or restructuring debt, reducing costs, and increasing equity, provided these plans are feasible and their implementation is probable.
questions.tip: Mitigating plans must be specific, feasible, and probable to implement.

questions.question: The emphasis-of-matter paragraph for going concern should:

options.A: Provide the auditor's opinion on whether the entity will survive
options.B: Refer to the relevant footnote disclosure and state the uncertainty
options.C: List all conditions creating substantial doubt
options.D: Include management's response to the uncertainty

questions.explanation: The emphasis paragraph should state that substantial doubt exists about the entity's ability to continue as a going concern and refer readers to the note in the financial statements containing the related disclosures.
questions.tip: Emphasis paragraph = state uncertainty + reference the disclosure note.

questions.question: Audit documentation for going concern should include:

options.A: Only the conclusion reached
options.B: Conditions identified, procedures performed, and conclusions reached
options.D: A copy of the emphasis paragraph

questions.explanation: Documentation should include conditions and events identified, procedures performed to evaluate going concern, management's plans and the auditor's evaluation, and the conclusion reached about the need for disclosure.
questions.tip: Document: conditions + procedures + plans evaluation + conclusions.

questions.question: Going concern conditions should be evaluated:

options.A: Individually, with only the largest issue considered
options.B: In the aggregate, considering the combined effect of all conditions
options.C: Only if requested by the audit committee
options.D: Separately by each audit team member

questions.explanation: Conditions and events should be considered in the aggregate. Individual conditions may not create substantial doubt, but their combined effect might indicate the entity cannot meet obligations.
questions.tip: Consider all conditions together. Combined effect may be significant.

questions.question: In a first-year audit, going concern evaluation:

options.A: Is not required
options.B: Requires additional consideration due to limited history with the client
options.D: Should be performed only by the predecessor auditor

questions.explanation: In a first-year audit, the auditor may have less historical knowledge about the entity, requiring additional procedures and skepticism when evaluating going concern conditions and management's representations.
questions.tip: First year = less history, more scrutiny needed in going concern evaluation.

questions.question: Going concern matters should be communicated to:

options.A: Only management
options.B: Those charged with governance

questions.explanation: The auditor should communicate to those charged with governance the events or conditions identified that may cast significant doubt on the entity's ability to continue as a going concern.
questions.tip: Going concern = governance communication. They need to know.

questions.question: If management's plans successfully alleviate substantial doubt, the auditor:

options.A: Must still include an emphasis paragraph
options.B: May issue an unmodified opinion without an emphasis paragraph

questions.explanation: If management's plans are probable and will effectively mitigate the conditions within the evaluation period, substantial doubt may be alleviated. No emphasis paragraph is required if no substantial doubt exists.
questions.tip: Plans alleviate doubt = no emphasis paragraph needed. Regular unmodified opinion.

questions.question: When evaluating management's cash flow projections for going concern, the auditor should:

options.A: Accept projections prepared by qualified personnel
options.B: Evaluate the reliability of underlying data and reasonableness of assumptions
options.D: Only review projections for mathematical accuracy

questions.explanation: The auditor evaluates whether projections are based on reasonable assumptions, supported by reliable data, and whether management's process for preparing them is appropriate. Material changes from historical patterns require scrutiny.
questions.tip: Cash flow projections: test data reliability + assumption reasonableness + process.

questions.question: A loan covenant violation at year-end may raise going concern issues because:

options.A: It always results in immediate loan acceleration
options.B: The lender may demand immediate repayment, threatening liquidity
options.D: The company must disclose it in the notes

questions.explanation: Covenant violations may give lenders the right to accelerate loan payments or refuse renewals. This potential for demanded repayment can threaten the entity's liquidity and ability to continue operations.
questions.tip: Covenant violation = lender may call loan. Threatens liquidity and going concern.

questions.question: If management's going concern plans rely on financial support from a related party:

options.A: The plan automatically alleviates substantial doubt
options.B: The auditor should verify the related party's ability and intent to provide support
options.D: The related party must be identified as a subsequent event

questions.explanation: Support from related parties is not automatically reliable. The auditor should evaluate the related party's financial ability to provide support and obtain evidence of their intent and commitment to do so.
questions.tip: Related party support: verify ability + intent + commitment. Get evidence.

questions.question: Information about going concern obtained after year-end but before report date:

options.A: Is not relevant to the evaluation
options.B: Should be considered in evaluating going concern
options.C: Only matters if it is positive news

questions.explanation: The auditor considers all information obtained through the report date, including subsequent events that provide evidence about conditions existing at year-end or conditions arising subsequently that affect going concern.
questions.tip: Subsequent information is relevant. Could improve or worsen the assessment.

questions.question: For private companies, going concern evaluation:

options.A: Is not required
options.B: Follows the same GAAP requirements as public companies
options.C: Is only required if the company has debt
options.D: Uses different criteria than public companies

questions.explanation: GAAP going concern requirements (ASC 205-40) apply to all entities, both public and private. The same evaluation criteria and disclosure requirements apply, though practical considerations may vary.
questions.tip: GAAP going concern applies to all entities. Private companies follow same rules.

questions.question: The management representation letter should include representations about:

options.A: The company's expected profitability
options.B: Management's plans and their feasibility when substantial doubt exists
options.C: Guarantee that the company will continue

questions.explanation: When substantial doubt exists, management should represent their evaluation, the plans they have developed, and the feasibility of those plans. This supplements but does not replace the auditor's evaluation.
questions.tip: Management represents: their evaluation + plans + feasibility assessment.

questions.question: When management's plans include selling assets to alleviate going concern, the auditor should consider:

options.A: Only the book value of the assets
options.B: Whether assets can be sold at values sufficient to resolve the conditions and in the required timeframe
options.C: Whether management has listed the assets for sale
options.D: The original cost of the assets

questions.explanation: The auditor evaluates whether the assets can realistically be sold, at what price, and whether the proceeds would be sufficient and timely enough to address the conditions causing substantial doubt.
questions.tip: Asset sale plans: Can they sell? At what price? Fast enough? Sufficient proceeds?

questions.question: When management's going concern plans rely on refinancing debt, the auditor should evaluate:

options.A: Only management's confidence in obtaining financing
options.B: Historical relationship with lenders and current credit market conditions
options.C: Whether the company has previously refinanced
options.D: The interest rate on existing debt

questions.explanation: The auditor considers the entity's historical financing relationships, current credit markets, the entity's credit profile, and whether indications exist that refinancing is achievable. Mere intent is insufficient.
questions.tip: Refinancing plans: lender relationships + credit markets + entity's creditworthiness.

questions.question: Industry-wide economic difficulties:

options.A: Automatically create going concern doubt
options.B: Should be considered when evaluating the entity's specific circumstances
options.C: Are not relevant to individual company going concern
options.D: Require emphasis paragraphs for all companies in the industry

questions.explanation: Industry-wide difficulties provide context for evaluating the entity but don't automatically create substantial doubt. The auditor considers how industry conditions specifically affect the entity's ability to continue.
questions.tip: Industry problems = context, not automatic doubt. How does it affect THIS entity?

questions.question: The liquidation basis of accounting should be used when:

options.A: Any going concern doubt exists
options.B: Liquidation is imminent and the going concern basis is no longer appropriate

questions.explanation: Liquidation basis accounting is required when liquidation is imminent - either through approval of a plan or other circumstances making liquidation inevitable. Going concern basis is inappropriate at that point.
questions.tip: Liquidation basis only when liquidation is imminent. Going concern doubt â‰  liquidation.

questions.question: Recurring operating losses are a going concern indicator because:

options.A: All companies with losses will fail
options.B: They may deplete resources needed to meet obligations
options.C: They require restatement of prior periods

questions.explanation: Recurring losses consume cash and equity, potentially depleting resources needed to pay debts and continue operations. However, losses alone don't create substantial doubt if other resources or plans exist.
questions.tip: Recurring losses = drain on resources. Consider cash flows and other factors too.

questions.question: A working capital deficiency indicates going concern risk because:

options.A: It means the company has no assets
options.B: Current liabilities exceed current assets, suggesting potential difficulty meeting short-term obligations

questions.explanation: Working capital deficiency (current liabilities exceeding current assets) suggests the entity may have difficulty meeting short-term obligations with available resources, though other factors must be considered.
questions.tip: Working capital deficit = short-term liquidity pressure. One indicator among several.

questions.question: Under PCAOB standards for public company audits, the auditor's going concern responsibility:

options.A: Is less rigorous than GAAS
options.B: Includes evaluating management's assessment and concluding on substantial doubt
options.C: Is delegated to the audit committee

questions.explanation: PCAOB standards require the auditor to evaluate whether there is substantial doubt about the entity's ability to continue as a going concern for a reasonable period, considering management's assessment and plans.
questions.tip: PCAOB going concern: evaluate management's assessment + reach own conclusion.

questions.question: Going concern evaluation through the report date may result in:

options.A: Different conclusions than if evaluated only at year-end
options.B: No change from year-end evaluation
options.D: Extending the evaluation beyond one year

questions.explanation: Events between year-end and report date can change the going concern assessment - either improving conditions (successful refinancing) or worsening them (major customer loss). The auditor considers all information through report date.
questions.tip: Things change between year-end and report date. Evaluate through report date.

questions.question: For startup companies with limited operating history and initial losses:

options.A: Going concern evaluation is not required
options.B: Standard going concern criteria still apply but context of stage of development is considered
options.C: An emphasis paragraph is always required
options.D: The auditor should disclaim an opinion

questions.explanation: Startups must still be evaluated for going concern using the same criteria. However, the auditor considers that initial losses and limited history are typical for startups, while also examining funding plans and business prospects.
questions.tip: Startups: same criteria but consider developmental stage. Focus on funding and prospects.
